factoid: The night was foggy.
The moonlight gleamed mysteriously through the fog.
Prince Andrew thought, "Tomorrow everything may be over for me."
All of Prince Andrew’s memories will be no more and will have no meaning for him.
Prince Andrew has a presentiment that for the first time he will have to show all that he can do.
Prince Andrew pictured a battle, its loss, concentration of fighting at one point, and the hesitation of all commanders.
Prince Andrew pictured a happy moment, the Toulon for which he had waited long.
Prince Andrew firmly and clearly expressed his opinion to Kutúzov, Weyrother, and the Emperors.
All of them were struck by the justness of Prince Andrew’s views.
No one undertook to carry out Prince Andrew’s views.
Prince Andrew took a regiment and a division and stipulated that no one interfere with his arrangements.
Prince Andrew led his division to the decisive point and gained the victory alone.
Another voice suggested, "But death and suffering?"
Prince Andrew did not answer that voice and continued dreaming of his triumphs.
Prince Andrew planned the dispositions for the next battle alone.
Prince Andrew was nominally an adjutant on Kutúzov’s staff, but he did everything alone.
The next battle was won by Prince Andrew alone.
Kutúzov was removed and Prince Andrew was appointed.
Another voice asked, "If before that you are not ten times wounded, killed, or betrayed, what then?"
Prince Andrew answered, "I don't know what will happen and don't want to know."
Prince Andrew wants glory, wants to be known to men, and wants to be loved by them.
Prince Andrew says it is not his fault that he wants glory and that he lives only for it.
Prince Andrew says he will never tell anyone.
Prince Andrew fears nothing, including death, wounds, and loss of family.
Prince Andrew would give his father, sister, and wife for a moment of glory.
Prince Andrew thinks about love from men he does not know.
Prince Andrew listened to voices in Kutúzov’s courtyard.
The voices were those of the orderlies packing up.
One voice, probably a coachman’s, teased Kutúzov’s old cook called Tit.
The old cook said, "Tit, I say, Tit!"
The wag said, "Go, Tit, thresh a bit!"
A voice called out, "Oh, go to the devil!" drowned by laughter.
Prince Andrew loves and values nothing but triumph over them all.
Prince Andrew values the mystic power and glory floating above him in the mist.
